metadata.finished_text: Reasoned about image analysis for 19 seconds

parts:
A succinct way to see why the answer is about 19 dB is to start from the Friis‐transmission formula.  In its linear form for two identical antennas,

\[
\frac{P_r}{P_t}
\;=\;
G^2 \,\bigl(\tfrac{\lambda}{4\pi R}\bigr)^2,
\]

where \(G\) is the (linear) gain of each antenna, \(\lambda\) is the wavelength, and \(R\) is the separation (12 m). We know \(P_r\) is 30 dB below \(P_t\), i.e.\(\,P_r/P_t = 10^{-3}\). At 5 GHz, the wavelength is
\[
\lambda \;=\;\frac{c}{f}\;=\;\frac{3\times10^8\text{\,m/s}}{5\times10^9\text{\,Hz}} \;=\;0.06\text{\,m}.
\]
Hence,
\[
10^{-3}
\;=\;
G^2\,\bigl(\tfrac{0.06}{4\pi\,\times\,12}\bigr)^2.
\]
The factor \(\tfrac{0.06}{4\pi\times 12}\approx 3.98\times10^{-4},\) so
\[
\bigl(\tfrac{0.06}{4\pi\,\times\,12}\bigr)^2
\;\approx\;
1.58\times10^{-7}.
\]
Solving for \(G^2\),
\[
G^2 \;=\;\frac{10^{-3}}{1.58\times10^{-7}}
\;\approx\;6.33\times10^3
\;\;\Rightarrow\;\;
G\;\approx\;79.6.
\]
Converting that to dB (i.e.\  \(G_\mathrm{dB} = 10\,\log_{10}(G)\)) gives
\[
G_\mathrm{dB} \;\approx\; 10\,\log_{10}(79.6)
\;\approx\; 19\text{\,dB}.
\]
Thus each antenna’s gain is about 19 dB under those test conditions.
